follow.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to go, walk, drive etc behind or after someone else
follow.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The patrol car followed the BMW for a few miles and then lost it.
Tom’s already gone out to Rome and his wife and children will follow shortly.
Peggy followed her out onto the landing.
follow.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to happen or do something after something else
follow.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The agreement followed months of negotiation.
The assassination of Martin Luther King in 1968 was followed by that of Robert Kennedy.
Most EU countries have signed the agreement and the US is expected to follow shortly (=soon).
After weeks of intense fighting, there followed a brief period of calm.
follow.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to come directly after something else in a series, list, or order
follow.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: The chapters that follow deal mainly with mathematics.
In English, the letter Q is always followed by U.
We had vegetable casserole with a fruit salad to follow  (=as part of a meal).
There followed several pages of incomprehensible statistics.
follow.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to do something in the way that someone has told or advised you to do it
follow.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: He followed the doctor’s advice and had no further trouble.
Follow the instructions very carefully when filling in the form.
They followed the plan that Elizabeth had worked out.
follow.translation[0].definitions[4].def: to do the same thing as someone else
follow.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: Some state schools follow the example of private schools in asking parents to donate money.
Environmentalists are urging the government to follow the lead of Scandinavian countries in this matter.
She’s just like any young woman who enjoys following the latest fashions  (=wearing fashionable clothes).
He does not want to follow his father into a scientific career.
follow.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to believe in and obey a particular set of religious or political ideas
follow.translation[0].definitions[6].def: to continue along a particular road, river etc
follow.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: I followed the main road up the mountain.
Tom followed the track that leads to the old Roman road.
follow.translation[0].definitions[7].def: to go in the same direction as something else, or to go parallel to something else
follow.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: The road follows the line of the river.
follow.translation[0].definitions[8].def: to understand something such as an explanation or story
follow.translation[0].definitions[8].exa: I didn’t quite follow what he was saying.
The plot is a little difficult to follow.
follow.translation[0].definitions[9].def: to be true as a result of something else that is true
follow.translation[0].definitions[9].exa: It doesn’t necessarily follow that you’re going to do well academically even if you’re highly intelligent.
The conclusion that follows from these findings is that inner city schools need more investment, not less.
follow.translation[0].definitions[10].de: to be interested in something and in the way it develops
follow.translation[0].definitions[10].ex: Have you been following that crime series on TV?
I’ve been following his progress very closely.
She just doesn’t understand people who follow football or any other kind of sport.
follow.translation[0].definitions[11].de: to show or describe someone’s life or a series of events, for example in a film or book
follow.translation[0].definitions[11].ex: The book follows the plight of an orphaned Irish girl who marries into New York society.
follow.translation[0].definitions[12].de: to carefully watch someone do something
follow.translation[0].definitions[12].ex: She followed Simon with her eyes as he walked to the gate.
follow.translation[0].definitions[13].de: to study or think about a particular idea or subject and try to learn something from it
follow.translation[0].definitions[13].ex: It turned out we were both following the same line of research.
If you follow that idea to its logical conclusion, we’d have to ban free speech altogether.
follow.translation[0].definitions[14].de: to look at the messages sent by a particular person using the social networking service Twitter
follow.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: follow
to walk, drive etc behind or after someone, for example in order to see where they are going
The man had followed her home to find out where she lived.
Follow that car!
He hired a detective to follow her.
chase
to quickly run or drive after someone or something in order to catch them when they are trying to escape
Police chased the car along the motorway at speeds of up to 90 mph.
run after somebody/go after somebody
to quickly follow someone or something in order to stop them or talk to them
I ran after him to say sorry, but he’d already got on the bus.
stalk
to secretly follow an animal in order to kill it, or to secretly follow a person in order to attack them
a tiger stalking its prey
He had a long history of stalking women in his neighbourhood.
pursue
to chase someone in a very determined way
The ship was being pursued by enemy submarines.
give chase
to chase someone or something who is trying to escape from you
One of the officers gave chase and arrested the man.
The calf ran away and the lion gave chase.
tail
to secretly follow someone in order to watch what they do and where they go
Apparently, the police had been tailing the terrorists for months.
track
to follow and find a person or animal by looking at the marks they leave on the ground
The bushmen were tracking antelope in the Kalahari desert.
follow.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The company’s decision to diversify follows a sharp decline in demand for its products.
As the recession worsened, further closures followed.
follow.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to be sent or paid later
follow.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: You can pay a deposit of £400 now, with the balance to follow within 30 days.
follow.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to do something in the way that someone has told or advised you to do it, or according to the instructions that say how it should be done
follow.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: If you’d followed my advice, we’d still be in profit.
The contractor was fined for failing to follow proper safety procedures.
Just follow the guidelines contained in this report.
follow.translation[1].definitions[3].def: to act according to a particular plan or set of ideas
follow.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: The Chancellor is expected to follow a cautious economicpolicy.
The company had followed the wrong strategy.
follow.translation[1].definitions[4].def: to happen or develop in the same way as something else
follow.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: These recent mergers appear to be following a trend.
If one company drops its prices, the others have to follow suit (=do the same thing).
follow.translation[1].definitions[5].def: to do a particular job or trade
follow.translation[1].definitions[5].exa: He intends to follow a legal career.
